event.title: <show-title>Purple Rain</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Pay tribute to the life, the music, and the legacy of Prince
event.description:
Dearly beloved, we are gathered here 2day 2 get through this thing called life – and to celebrate the legacy of the visionary and singular musical force that was Prince.

PURPLE RAIN is the semi-autobiographical tale of The Kid, a Minneapolis musician navigating the club scene while dealing with a romantic rival and a difficult family life. A massive hit upon release, it's a showcase for the Purple One’s otherworldly musical, visual, and sartorial stylings, and introduced the world to the glory of "When Doves Cry," "Let's Go Crazy," and of course, "Purple Rain." Join us in honoring His Royal Badness with a rockin’ Movie Party featuring purple shades, inflatable guitars, and funky fiber optic wands – in purple, of course.

As the man himself once sang, “U better live now.” Words 2 live by.

contentBlocks.paragraphs:

show.title: The Wizard of Oz (1939)
show.headline: Head back over the rainbow and re-experience the land of Oz

event.title: <show-title>The Wizard of Oz (1939)</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Journey over the rainbow to this fun-for-the-family interactive adventure
event.description:
There’s no place like Alamo Drafthouse. At this special interactive Movie Party screening, we’ll have magical props to take with you on your way into Emerald City, including hair ribbons, lollipops (Guild-approved, of course), postcards, and even a little basket to carry it all home in.

So lock arms with your merry band of friends and skip on down the yellow brick road to join us for what promises to be a real whirlwind of a party. Ruby slippers very much encouraged.

show.title: Vampire's Kiss

show.title: Hot Fuzz
show.headline: Edgar Wright's silly deconstruction of the buddy cop genre

event.title: <show-title>Hot Fuzz</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Big cops. Small town. Moderate violence.
event.description:
By the power of Greyskull, join us for an interactive celebration of director Edgar Wright’s balls-to-the-wall supercop comedy masterpiece, HOT FUZZ! Wright and his collaborators Simon Pegg and Nick Frost do to action cinema what they did to horror in SHAUN OF THE DEAD: They walk the cleverest of lines between homage, parody, and downright badass awesomeness. And when you model yourself after movies like POINT BREAK and BAD BOYS II, how could the results be anything but spectacular?

We’re even equipping you with everything you need to join the Sandford Police Service, including police badges, mustaches, and aviator glasses.

show.title: Grease
show.headline: Summer lovin' lives on in this quintessential movie musical celebrating the '50s

event.title: <show-title>Grease</show-title> <event-type-title>Sing-Along Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Warm up your pipes for a systematic, hydromatic sing-along
event.description:
We’re hopelessly devoted to GREASE, with its lovable characters, doo-wop style, and, of course, those endlessly catchy tunes. To celebrate this timeless classic, we’re putting together an interactive, prop-filled, hand-jiving Sing-Along Movie Party for all you T-Birds and Pink Ladies out there (beauty school dropouts also welcome).

We’ll kick things off with a pre-show hand jive contest before we start the interactive show, where you’ll have some candy cigarettes to help you look like a greaser, a comb so that you can comb along to the action, pom poms in Rydell High colors, and beauty caps to help you get the perfect ‘do. And because this is a Sing-Along, we’ll have the lyrics up onscreen to help every Danny, Sandy, Rizzo, and Kenickie in the audience get in on the fun.

So roll up the cuffs on those jeans, grab your respective black leather and pink satin jackets, theatrically comb your hair, and cruise on down to join us for the most rockin’ Sing-Along Movie Party ever.

DCP courtesy of Paramount Pictures

landscapeHeroImage.altText: Grease Sing Along Web SHOW Hero 1920x1080 v3

posterImage.altText: Grease Sing Along Web SHOW P 960x1400

show.title: Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!
show.headline: A love story...with strings attached

landscapeHeroImage.altText: TIE ME UP! TIE ME DOWN!

portraitHeroImage.altText: TIE ME UP! TIE ME DOWN!

posterImages.altText: TIE ME UP! TIE ME DOWN!

event.title: <show-title>Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!</show-title>
event.headline: Another unmissable Almodóvar/Banderas collaboration.
event.description:
“You'd better tie me up.”

We’re getting un poquito controversial here at Queer Film Theory 101! While most of the films we screen are box office hits that we extract queerness from, this month we’re examining one of the earliest films to receive an NC-17 rating: Pedro Almodovar’s divisive classic TIE ME UP! TIE ME DOWN!

When “cured” psychiatric patient Ricky (Antonio Banderas) finds himself adrift and alone after release, he fixates on B-movie and pornographic film star Marina (Victoria Abril), enacting a plan to kidnap her in the hope that she will fall in love with him.

Following on the heels of his star-making film WOMEN ON THE VERGE OF A NERVOUS BREAKDOWN, TIE ME UP! maintains a complicated relationship with viewers and critics alike (Roger Ebert said the film made him “feeling increasingly left out,” and to that, we say, "Sweetheart, if you wanna be tied up too, you just have to ask). While some viewers bristle at the film's more problematic elements, many find it an excellent critique of gender dynamics with a sly sense of humor. Interrogating themes of consent, coercion, sanism, and bondage, TIE ME UP! TIE ME DOWN! is a hilarious and uncomfortable investigation into the gilded cage of heteronormativity from one of our favorite queer directors, and we highly recommend you take this opportunity to catch it on the big screen. Note: we “recommend” it, meaning we won't make you watch it. Let’s go agency! Let’s go autonomy! Let’s go enthusiastic consent! (Micheal Foulk)

DCP courtesy of Janus Films.

Queer Film Theory 101 at Alamo Drafthouse takes an in-depth look at the queerest “straight” films ever produced. We’re outing all of your favorite films! Is TITANIC a genderqueer love story? Yeah! Does POINT BREAK explore latent homosexuality in sports culture? Absolutely. Is JAWS about the violent fear of queer desire? Yes yes, and we’ll tell you why. To this day there are so few representations of LGBTQ+ people in film, so we improvise, we read between the lines, we make adjustments to our head cannon, and zero in on all the queer subtext available. Join us every month for a new entry in our screening and lecture series. Hosted in-person in San Francisco; pre-recorded introductions elsewhere.

eventType.title: Special Event
eventType.headline: For Movie Lovers, by Movie Lovers
eventType.description: Whether it’s a movie-inspired feast, an interactive party, or a screening paired with a live performance, we love sharing the movies we love in new and exciting ways.

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: Jaws (1975)
show.headline: Steven Spielberg's terrifying creature feature

event.title: <show-title>Jaws (1975)</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: A bigger boatload of bite-y fun
event.description:
“This shark, swallow you whole.”

Duh, nuh…duh, nuh…nothing quite says "ah, summer" like watching an elusive giant shark terrorize Amity Island on the big screen. It’s the movie that perfected the summer blockbuster and launched a million toothy (and goofy) knock-offs, but none of them can compete with the bite of Spielberg’s 1975 original. This bona fide American classic has everything you could want from a movie: kids in peril, drunken sea shanties, and Richard Dreyfuss in a cage.

As if that wasn’t enough, this is a Movie Party, so you can live the shark-hunting adventure along with your pals Brody, Hooper, and Quint – minus the salty sea air and actual mortal peril. Featuring Shark Hats, Yellow Floatie Drink Holders (CAUTION: very susceptible to shark attacks), and other surprises, it’s the most fourth-wall-busting fun you can have on dry land.

show.title: Challengers
show.headline: Love is a game – you play to win, or you lose

show.title: Pet Sematary (1989)
show.headline: Sometimes dead is better

event.title: <show-title>Pet Sematary (1989)</show-title>
event.headline: Sometimes dead is better
event.description: Mary Lambert's 1989 adaptation of the Stephen King horror-literature classic stars Dale Midkiff as a veterinarian who, after suffering tragedy in his family, dips his toes into supernatural power he does not fully understand. Creepy kids, creepier animals, and Fred Gwynne sporting a beyond-memorable Maine accent – PET SEMATARY is responsible for unleashing waves of nightmare fuel upon an unsuspecting generation of horror hounds. Just a mention of “Zelda” sends a shiver down the spine of those in the know. Don’t miss a chance to see this still spooky creepfest on the big screen via a 4K digital restoration.

show.headline: Take home a gruesome MAXXXINE souvenir with our THE PURITAN II VHS Case

event.title: <show-title>MaXXXine</show-title> <event-type-title>Early Access</event-type-title>
event.headline: See Mia Goth in Ti West's bloody finale before anyone else
event.description: Two generations of terror and countless bodies have all built to this, and if you’re anything like us, you can’t wait a second longer to see it. Join us for a special Early Access screening of MAXXXINE to see the explosive finale of Ti West’s X trilogy before anyone else.

contentBlocks.paragraphs: Two generations of terror and countless bodies have all built to this, and if you’re anything like us, you can’t wait a second longer to see it. Join us for a special Early Access screening of MAXXXINE to see the explosive finale of Ti West’s X trilogy before anyone else.

imageAsset.title: Ma XX Xine Merch Web Deluxe Showpage 1920x1080 1
imageAsset.caption: This gruesome Alamo-exclusive is only available with advance tickets to MAXXXINE

image.altText: MAXXXINE Limited Edition The Puritan II VHS Case

contentBlocks.paragraphs: We dug through our archives to find this (fictional) piece of Hollywood history – a limited-edition VHS Case for Maxine Minx’s feature debut, THE PURITAN II. This gruesome Alamo-exclusive is only available with advance tickets to MAXXXINE and comes stuffed with bonus stickers, a button, and MAXXXINE headshot. Supplies are limited, so add one to your MAXXXINE ticket order while you can.

show.title: Easy Rider

show.title: X
show.headline: Director Ti West is dying to show you a good time

event.title: <show-title>X</show-title> <event-type-title>Fan Event Featuring MAXXXINE Sneak Peek</event-type-title>
event.eventTypeTitleOverride: Fan Event Featuring MAXXXINE Sneak Peek
event.headline: Ti West's twisted, bloddy slasher with a MAXXXINE sneak peek
event.description: Before Maxine Minx found stardom in the glitz and glam of Hollywood, she was in a little-seen “art” movie filmed at a remote farm in Texas. See how the budding starlet got her start at an exclusive fan event for Ti West’s bloody and titillating slasher, X. Not only will you get a chance to see Mia Goth’s star-making turn as the fame-hungry scream queen, you’ll get a 6-minute sneak peek at the upcoming finale of the terrifying trilogy, MAXXXINE. Plus, it’s on a Tuesday, so you’ll enjoy a discounted price on every ticket.

show.title: UHF
show.headline: Don't touch that dial!

event.title: <show-title>UHF</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Don't touch that dial!
event.description:
To celebrate the cult comedy UHF, we're throwing a Movie Party! Not only do you get to watch this uproarious classic with a theater full of fellow "Weird Al" fans, but we'll also have all sorts of fun props to help you get in on the action, including TV signal glasses, gummy hot dogs, and fake mustaches.

So throw on a Hawaiian shirt, grab a spatula, and join us as we cheer on "Weird Al" in his fight to keep his local UHF station out of the hands of evil corporate overlords.

event.headline: Treat your little Minions to a despicably fun party
event.description: Kids love Minions. They also love fun props that they can play with during a movie. Put those two awesome things together and you get our DESPICABLE ME 4 Family Party. Your little Minions will have a despicably fun time with themed souvenirs (bananas included, of course.) Your ticket includes the movie, the props, and even an extra craft activity sheet so you can keep the party going back home.

eventType.title: Family Party
eventType.headline: Take the whole family to an immersive cinematic spectacular
eventType.description: Our lobbies become your family’s place to celebrate film in wacky and immersive ways, with themed games, hands-on crafts, and activities before the show.

titleCardImage.altText: Family Party TT2

show.title: Field of Dreams
show.headline: If you believe the impossible, the incredible can come true

show.title: Firestarter (1984)
show.headline: Will she have the power...to survive?

event.title: <show-title>Firestarter (1984)</show-title>
event.headline: Will she have the power...to survive?
event.description:
No matter what script you start with, any film with the stars of PATTON, APOCALYPSE NOW, and E.T. – all directed by the guy who did CLASS OF 1984 – is gonna turn out pretty wonderful. What a bonus, then, to have it be a whackadoo Stephen King adaptation! Originally published during the snowstorm of King’s heavy-duty, well-publicized cocaine years, FIRESTARTER’s telekinesis conspiracy plot makes as much sense as a Weng Weng movie, but who cares? It’s worth the price of admission alone to see the audacious dialogue scenes between a karate-chopping George C. Scott and a pissed-off eight-year-old Drew Barrymore. Add a Martin Sheen that’s somehow even more oily than his DEAD ZONE counterpart, a John Carpenter-like score by Tangerine Dream, and enough pyro to outdo a Metallica stadium show, and you’ve got a late-night, three-beers genre bull's eye.

DCP courtesy of Universal Pictures

show.title: Crimes of Passion
show.headline: She is watched. She is worshipped. And she must remain a mystery.

event.title: <show-title>Crimes of Passion</show-title>
event.headline: Ken Russell's combustible erotic thriller
event.description:
“I am the messenger of God, you little cocksucker!”

Where do we even begin…y’all, we love some Ken Russell over here in the House of Theory. Ken was known for their flamboyant and controversial films that spanned decades and genres. From the Academy Award-winning drama WOMEN IN LOVE to the bizarre and hedonistic historical horror THE DEVILS to his many biopics of romantic-era composers, Russell tried it all. CRIMES OF PASSION, written by gay screenwriter Barry Sandler, is one of Russell’s few films firmly rooted in the era it was born into: the excessive and turbulent '80s. Joanna Crane (Kathleen Turner) is a frustrated fashion designer who moonlights as a sex worker under the alias China Blue. When she begins a complicated and intimate relationship with unsatisfied surveillance freelancer Bobby Grady (John Laughlin), Joanna’s delicately balanced life begins to topple. Meanwhile, psychotic street preacher Peter Shayne (Anthony Perkins) stalks Joanna, intent on “saving” her immortal soul no matter what it takes. THIS MOVIE IS NUTS, Y’ALL. CRIMES had a tumultuous path to the screen after the MPAA threatened to brand it with the dreaded X rating due to its salacious subject matter. After a death by a thousand cuts, the film was released to middling and confused reviews, AND YET we here a Queer Film Theory 101 think CRIMES OF PASSION is one of Russel’s most important and searing interrogations of repression, sexuality, religion, and otherness. And it is mad queer and deviant in all the right ways: there’s a metal murder dildo called Superman, y’all. Join us for a little taste of summertime smut – it’ll be good for you. We promise.

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: Footloose (1984)
show.headline: The music is on his side

event.title: <show-title>Footloose (1984)</show-title>
event.headline: The music is on his side
event.description: It’s time to lace up your Converse high tops and hit the abandoned industrial facility for some anxiety-fueled dance gymnastics because this month, Queer Film Theory 101 is cutting FOOTLOOSE. The small conservative rural community of Bomont is rocked when androgynous Chicago teen Ren McCormick (Kevin Bacon) moves to town and rejects the local ban on dancing. A town with no dancing? Jump back! That sounds an awful lot like a town with a drag ban, and that’s some bullshit. Also wouldn’t that be remarkably hard to enforce? Because I’m wiggling my hips while I’m writing this and who’s gonna stop me? Now, sometimes the queer read we posit on Queer Film Theory 101 is a stretch, but that is simply not the case when it comes to this '80s classic. From Bacon and Chris Penn’s “Let’s Hear It For The Boy” homoerotic dance lessons to the religious overtones of Reverend Shaw’s (John Lithgow) vendetta against undulating bodies, this movie is pretty damn camp. It’s not a huge leap in logic to see how “dancing” in FOOTLOOSE is a metaphor for queerness. Hell, there’s even a church “coming out” scene, and Dianne Wiest and Sarah Jessica Parker are in this movie – it’s for the gays and the dolls, y’all. While FOOTLOOSE wasn’t exactly well received critically (Roger Ebert called it “a seriously confused movie that tries to do three things, and does all of them badly” and that shit sounds pretty damn queer to me) the film and its soundtrack were commercial hits and skyrocketed Bacon to stardom. See you on the dance floor, baby!

marketStrings.value: The personal closed captioning device displays feature film dialogue and other audio in the form of English-language text for individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing.

The descriptive audio headset provides individuals who are blind or have low vision with an English-language narration of the details of the feature presentation that can't be understood by the soundtrack alone.

Upon request at the box office, we provide assistive listening headsets with amplified audio for those individuals who are hard of hearing. For guests who prefer to use their own hearing aids, neck loops, or cochlear implants, our assistive listening headsets have a 3.5mm headphone jack to connect to those devices.

In order to ensure the highest quality experience for all guests, you may not enter a movie after it has started. We’d love to see you up to 30 minutes early. Running late? No worries, we will happily exchange your ticket for a different showtime or a raincheck to a future show.

sessionAttributes.name: Baby Day Show
sessionAttributes.description: For our baby day shows, we keep the lights up a bit, and the sound down a bit, so your little one never has to know they even went to the movies!

sessionAttributes.name: Kid Friendly
sessionAttributes.description: Grab the fam and let the fun begin! Our Kid Friendly screenings include pre-show activity sheets and crayons, a relaxed noise policy, and kids menus. Ages 3+ welcome with a parent or guardian.
